Hydrochlor LLC Executive Summary:



The site has Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride stored in high pressure tubes in a quantity greater than the 112(R) list threshold quantity.



If a release or an accident would occur, there would be a significant impact on public receptors per modeling conducted by Linde for the worst case and alternative release scenarios. This modeling was performed in 2012.



Hydrochlor LLC is a new facility with construction and start-up completion in 2012.



Based on the above information the process mentioned, the process is considered program level 3 processes.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Hydrochlor Facility:



Safety is the first consideration in the design and operation of this plant.  Nevertheless there is always the possibility of equipment failure, operator error or force of nature which could cause a serious environmental problem. Hydrochlor is committed to making protection of human heath, safety and the environment the first priority. We will operate on the premise that all accidents and incidents are preventable and work toward this goal. 



Hydrochlor will fulfill this policy commitment through the application of a comprehensive Risk Management System which will provide all stakeholders with ongoing assurance that:



- Adherence to safety, heath and environmental laws, regulations, and permit requirements

- Identifiable safety, heath and environmental risks associated with Hydrochlor operation are assessed and successfully managed

- Systems are in place to manage change

- An environmental contingency plan is in place

- Emergency Response Procedures are in place

- An excellent safety performance is everyone's responsibility, and it is this site policy that all employees must adopt and are encourage safe work practices and conduct for all work related activities in an environmentally responsible manner.



General Information of the facility:



The Hydrochlor LLC facility is a joint

venture (JV) between Linde Gas North America, LLC and Air Products and Chemicals, Inc. that was established for the purpose of filling tube trailers and Y-cylinders with Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride manufactured by Dow.   The process is fed by liquid hydrogen chloride from the supplier's (Dow) existing pipeline. Dow operates and maintains a sub-cooler, sump and knock-out pot on the JV site for interface with the JV transfill equipment. 



A Milton Roy (MR) triplex pump transfers sub-cooled liquid to tube trailers and Y-cylinders. The MR pump is a positive displacement pump, therefore is fitted with a variable frequency drive (VFD) and a recycle loop, controlled by discharge pressure, tied back to the Dow subcooler sump. The purpose of the recycle loop is to maintain higher discharge pressure, particularly while filling Y-cylinders. 



There are two tube trailer fill stanchions, each with a truck scale, and one dump stanchion. There is an additional truck scale on site for check weighing that is not associated with dump or fill stanchions. There are four Y-cylinder fill stanchions, each with cylinder scale, and one dump stanchion. There is an additional cylinder scale on site for check weighing that is not associated with dump or fill stanchions. 



Tube trailers have connections at both the front (liquid) and back (gas) of the tubes. There is a single manifold to connect at the rear of the tube (gas connection), shared by the two tube trailer fill stanchions, that is used for analytical sampling and testing. The Y-cylinder fill stanchions do not have separate gas and liquid manifolds, in which case the Y-cylinder is rotated to spin the dip tube for either gas or liquid connection. 



In certain cases, tube trailers and Y-cylinders will be returned on site with a small heel of liquid that must be removed before re-filling the container. This liquid heel will be dumped to Dow's anhydrous HCl header, via Dow's knock-out pot on the JV site. Several times a month, tub

es and cylinders will be taken out of service to have the primary vessel valve replaced. In these cases, HCl vapor that is not dumped to the anhydrous header (typically 50 psig) will be vented through an absorber on site. The absorber is essentially a liquid contactor to remove HCl vapor from a gas stream. The resulting aqueous HCl will be returned to Dow at a rate of approximately 5 gpm. The absorber will operate continuously; therefore the concentration of HCl in the aqueous return stream will vary between 0% and 38% acid. 



After connections are made to the Y-cylinder or tube trailer, high pressure Nitrogen (1000 psig) will be used to insure no leaks. This Nitrogen will be vented down to the absorber. In addition to leak check, low pressure He will be used to purge lines after making connections and before line breaking, to maintain purity and prevent operator exposure, respectively. This low pressure He, (aka cycle purge) will also be vented to the absorber.



Regulated Substance Handled at the site:



Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride is used in the transfer pipeline from Dow, through the triplex pumps and filling manifold into tube trailers.   Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride is also used transfer lines between residual tube trailers and the disposal system including the absorber line going to DOW and the on site absorber.



The Worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario for Anhydrous Hydrogen Chloride at the Hydrochlor Site: 

WORST CASE SCENARIO



SELECTION CRITERIA & SCENARIO DESCRIPTION

Introduction: The Analysis was performed on a single 3,000 pound Hydrogen Chloride Storage tube. The location itself is surrounded by the DOW chemical facility.



The EPA's RMP*Comp Ver. 1.07 software was used for the analysis. This software product is widely used for air modeling applications. The scope of the analysis included modeling a worst case release scenario of a vessel rupture and an alternative release scenario of a release through temperature

and pressure activated relief valves.



The Worst Case Scenario (WCS) for the Hydrochlor Facility is the release of total contents of one 3,000 lb tube on a tube trailer in 10 minutes.  



Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, would have mitigated the release, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario.  The results for the WCS were generated from the EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines, (RMP).  

The release results were determined assuming the following conditions for a WCS:



?    Neutrally buoyant gas

?    Ten-minute release

?    Urban/obstacles topography

?    F stability class

?    Wind speed of 1.5 meters per second

?    Temperature of 77 deg F

Using census data from LandView 6, the estimated population within the worst case scenario circle is 24,758.

 



ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO



To assist in emergency response planning, the Linde Hydrochlor Facility developed an Alternative Release Scenario (ARS) to represent a reasonable "outer bound" for our emergency response planning and for explaining potential hazards to the community.



SELECTION CRITERIA & SCENARIO DESCRIPTIONS



To determine the most appropriate scenario for the ARS, the following steps were taken:



?    Using the HAZOP of the system,  a set of upset conditions was identified that could lead to a release of HCl

?    A conservative set of release conditions, physical characteristics of the release site, and meteorological conditions at the time of the release were identified for each upset condition

?    An analysis of the distance to each endpoint was performed to determine which release scenario had the highest likelihood of resulting in the greatest offsite impact.



Based on scenari

os generated during the HCl PHA, it was determined that the potential exists for a  9/16" rupture disk on a HCl tube to fail, releasing 3,000 lbs of HCl in 45 minutes.



Mitigation systems included the following:



?    Toxic gas monitors at trailer fill areas activate isolation of transfer valves

?    Anti-tow away measures isolate transfer valve

?    Controls logic detects deviations between flow-meter and scale to shut off pump and isolate transfer lines 

?    Remote isolation of transfer pump suction valve upon indication of release

?    Fire water spray monitor nozzles directed at HCl trailer loading area



The results for the ACS were generated from the EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines, (RMP).  The EPA's RMP*Comp Ver. 1.07 software was used for the analysis.



The release results were determined assuming the following conditions for an ACS:



?    Neutrally buoyant gas;

?    Three-minute release;

?    Urban/obstacles topography

?    D stability class;

?    Wind speed of 3 meters per second; and

?    Temperature of 77 deg F

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps:



The Hydrochlor plant process is designed and operated under strict parameters to reduce risk of accidents. The safety of Hydrochlor employees, the surrounding Dow employees and contractors and the citizens of the surrounding communities are of paramount importance. As a result of Hydrochlor's commitment to the safety of its employees, Its surrounding community, to fully comply with OSHA 'S standard 29 CFR 1910.119 (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals) Hydrochlor has a Process Sa

fety Management Program (PSM) . This Program is intended to prevent or reduced the risk of any major industrial incident that might expose employees to the Hazard of Toxicity, Fire, or explosion cause by highly hazardous chemicals.



The elements of the program are:



1. Employee Participation

2. Process Safety Information

3. Process Hazard Analysis

4 Operating Procedure

5. Training

6. Contractor Safety

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review

8. Mechanical Integrity

9. Hot Work Permit

10. Management Of Change

11. Incident Investigation

12. Emergency Response Plan

13. Compliance Audit

14 Trade Secrets



The objective of these provisions is to develop a protective approach to the identification, evaluation, and prevention of chemical releases which result from lack of procedures, human error, or equipment failure. 



Hydrochlor has also developed and implemented a Best Management Practice Plan prevents or minimize the potential for release of pollutants from ancillary activities, including material storage areas; plant site runoff; in-plant transfer and process areas.   The trailer filling areas have fire water monitors. Wind socks are also located within the site to determine wind direction. An emergency response plan is in place.



The Five Year Accident History:



The site has is a new facility as of 2012.



The Emergency Response Program:



The intent of the management at this site is to be pro-active, reduce risk, provide a safe, healthy work site and prevent accidents and emergencies from occurring as much as feasible. The Emergency Action Plan is developed to minimize threats to life, health and property when un-planed events happen. 



The emergency Response Program was developed base on the following Assumptions:



1. The control building is built as a shelter in place

2. Operations in the plant may be isolated on short notice from other sections

3. Personnel are trained operators who understand their section of the plant thoroughly and who have

been trained on steps to be taken to assure safe operation in that section

4. Hazardous releases from the surrounding Dow facility that could have an impact on Hydrochlor employees are monitored for and considered in the emergency response plan

5.  Employees of Hydrochlor and Dow are alerted and trained to respond to the tiered Dow emergency alarm system protocol:  Dow level 0 alarm (release is contained), Level 1 (release contained within block), Level 2 (release contained within DOW site), Level 3 (release is outside of DOW site).  



Hydrochlor in the event of an incident would need to rely on assistance from the DOW Emergency Operation Center. The existence of an emergency will be reported immediately by any individual calling 979-238-6666 (Dow Emergency Number) and 1-800-232-4726 (Linde Emergency Number). In order that the security officer realizes the urgency of the call, the individual reporting will state "emergency call". Facts to be reported to the emergency contact official will include the following:



- Name of the individual making the report

- Where the call is being made from

- Nature of occurrence

- Weather there has been loss of life or injury to personnel



If the incident involves a release, the proper Emergency Release Notifications must also be made:



-    EPA (If Reportable Quantity is exceeded)

-    Dow

-    Linde

-    Air Products



Further information that must be provided would include the following:



- Name of chemical release

- Estimated Quantity release

- Time and duration of release

- Release occurred in air, water or land

- Known or anticipated acute or chronic health risks and where appropriate, advice concerning medical

attention necessary for expose personnel

- Proper precautions to take as result of release including evacuations:



In House Training of Personnel Includes:



1) Linde On-Alert Training (Hazardous incident response training)

2) CPR Training

3) First Aid

4) Proper Use of Fire extinguisher. Training vid

eo.

5) Yearly Site Review of Emergency Action Plan

6) Yearly review of Environmental Plan

7) Monthly Safety Meetings where the site go over corrective actions to take for a specific emergency

Situation



Other Elements included in the Emergency Action Plan:



1) An emergency escape procedure and emergency escape assignment

2) Emergency shut-down procedures that can be activated by all employees

3) Procedures to account for all employees after an emergency evacuation has been completed

4) Dow emergency services for injuries beyond first aid

5) An Alarm system test schedule
